thread.title: Video: Hubbs proud of Vols' grit in comeback win
thread.title_full: Video: Hubbs proud of Vols' grit in comeback win

title: Video: Hubbs proud of Vols' grit in comeback win
text:
Robert Hubbs has been a sore guy the past couple of weeks while battling unspecified injuries — more than one injury, for what it’s worth. 
Things got even rougher Wednesday morning, when Tennessee’s star senior guard woke up with flu-like symptoms. 
Hubbs said it “would have taken a broken leg” to keep him off the floor Wednesday night against Ole Miss, though, and the senior toughed through all the aches to collect a game-high 18 points, four assists, two turnovers, one blocked shot, one steal and zero turnovers in 36 minutes to help the Vols rally past the Rebels for a huge, 75-66 win in Thompson-Boling Arena. Tennessee senior guard Robert Hubbs (Photo: Tennessee athletics, UTSports.com) 
(Want the latest scoop on Tennessee football and basketball? Make sure you're in the loop — take five seconds to sign up for our FREE Vols newsletter now!) 
Tennessee led for just 2 minutes, 8 seconds in Wednesday’s second half, but those were the final 2 minutes, 8 seconds of the game. Hubbs made much of it happen, too, with a steal, an assist and six points during the Vols’ game-ending, 15-2 run. 
Hubbs — who hit the go-ahead shot on a tough, left-handed bucket and added two free throws moments later to push that lead to two scores — said moments after the game that he still didn’t feel great physically but would sleep a lot better Wednesday night than he did after the Vols’ late collapse and loss at at Mississippi State on Saturday. 
The 6-foot-5 senior from rural West Tennessee said he was happy to see the Vols turn the screws on an opponent in the closing minutes — something they’ve struggled with much of the season. 
“We went out there and just took it,” Hubbs said. “We made big-time plays when we needed ‘em, and we went out there and took it.” 
(Buy one month of GoVols247 VIP access and GET TWO MONTHS FREE .) 
Hubbs said Tennessee’s entire team — even him, as the team’s most experienced player — is learning what it takes to grind out games like Wednesday, and he hopes to see that trend continue during the Vols’ February fight for an NCAA Tournament spot. 
“We’re all learning — including me, you know?” Hubbs said. “We’re all learning that in the last four or five minutes, you’ve got to go out there and take it. You can’t be hesitant. You have to be the aggressor.” 
Tennessee (14-10, 6-5 SEC) is back at home Saturday to face Georgia (13-11, 4-7) before traveling to 15th-ranked Kentucky (19-5, 9-2) for a Valentine’s Day showdown in Rupp Arena.
